As a Catholic I find this question to be quite interesting but simple, and to understand why so to give a sufficient answer we need to do a little history. Historically the Catholic Church is the original Christian church.  Barring the effects of wars (mostly due to Islamic and barbarian incursions), many of the churches mentioned in the New Testament (most notably and prominently Rome) have always been Catholic.  In the first centuries of the Early Church the Church Fathers  such as Justin Martyr (100–165 A.D.), Irenaeus (130 - 202 A.D.), Clement of Rome (d. 101 A.D.) and others are seen to express uniquely Catholic ideas and dogmas.  These men lived within a generation of the events of the New Testament and where contemporaries with some of its characters.  In fact Clement is said to be possibly identifiable with the Clement in Philipians 4:3 according to the Encyclopaedia Britannica. This aside, for many years as the reader likely knows, the Bible was not actually a book but largely retained in diverse scripts or in oral form according to the traditions of the ancient world.  These recitations and scripts formed the tradition of early (and provably Catholic) Christianity.  Christian was not a religion of the book, but of a tradition written and unwritten handed down generation to generation just as the Catholic church hands down its traditions and rites today. Eventually to sufficiently maintain and conserve the sacred texts of the Chistian religion, the Bible was put entirely to writing and began to be assembled as we might begin to see it today.  There was a problem however, many heretical scripts were circulating alongside legitimate ones.  Fast forward to the 4th century, the Church fathers (whom were admittedly Catholic mind you) gathered to together to solve among other things this problem with the scriptures.  In 397 A.D. they met in Carthage and determined and reconfirmed the books of the Bible as we know it today.  Some of these heretical texts included those such as the Gospel of Judas, Gnostic texts, and others that clearly had serious flaws and did not represent the Catholic Christian religion in the least. Fast forward again to the Protestant Revolt of the 16th century.  Early Lutherans and other Protestants wished to establish which sacred texts they would accept from the Catholic Canon as suitable for their new Christian religion.  Rejecting the Carthage canon as a means to differentiate themselves from the Catholic Churches, they threw out the Deuterocanonical books of the Old Testament.  These books had been similarly rejected by Jews at the Council of Jamnia 70–90 A.D.  These books were seen as ‘too Catholic’ containing concepts such as Purgatory, prayers for the dead, and intercession. TL;DR Hence we can see that the Protestant Bible really varies only in translation from the ancient languages, and the exclusion of a handful of traditionally Christian books.  Thus Protestant bibles are really Catholic bibles in different clothing, perhaps more Catholic by influence than most Protestants would be willing to admit. So how do we discard of a Protestant translation of the bible when it is badly damaged? (I fact own a few of Protestant translations myself)  Exactly as I would discard of a Catholic translation of the Bible. It is fairly easy in fact.  Just be respectful.  There is no canon law defining how a Bible ought to be discarded.  Some Catholics follow a custom of disposing of religious articles that have been blessed either by respectfully burying or burning them, but even that is not mandated.  If the Bible has been blessed you might choose to follow that custom.  A lot of Christians now long gone to their eternal reward spent a lot of effort to hand down and protect the Word of God for you. Sources: What is the appropriate means to dispose of an old Bible?

Any sacramental that is no longer usable should be returned to nature. Burying underground, sinking into a body of water, or respectfully burning are all options. I have a couple of things that I had set aside for proper disposal, and when the utility company had to dig on my property, I took that opportunity to bury them. Be advised that Bibles (books in general) can be very hard to burn in a regular fire unless printed on very cheap paper. You would have to pull out small thicknesses of pages and burn it bit by bit. I would never put a Bible in the trash, but I also wouldn’t recycle it, because it could be profaned while in the bin awaiting processing.

As a former Catholic, who went to twelve years of Catholic school, I cannot ever recall being told anything special about discarding of anyone's Bible, Catholic or otherwise, except that no one should trash a book if there is a poor person who wants to read it. Therefore, in my order of preference: (a) donate to a church or school, (b) donate to a used book store, (c) place into newspaper and paper recycling container, or (d) place into dumpster.
